questions.text: Treatment of choice in bronchiolitis is -
questions.solution:
Ribavirin, the only currently available antiviral medication targeting RSV, is also not currently recommended because of minimal impact on disease outcomes and because it is costly, difficult to administer, and associated with important toxicities.

Management of Bronchiolitis, in general is supportive.

Other options:

  • Amantadine, an antiviral agent is used for Influenza A treatment.
  • Vidarabine, an antiviral drug used to treat Herpes simplex encephalitis and Disseminated varicella-zoster infection
  • Nirsevimab, a one dose long-acting monoclonal antibody, is approved for prevention of RSV infection in newborns and infants. Another drug for prevention of RSV is Palivizumab

questions.text: Macrocephaly is seen in which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
A deficiency of aspartoacylase leads to Canavan disease, a severe leukodystrophy characterized by excessive excretion of NAA and spongy degeneration of the white matter of the brain.

Infants usually appear normal at birth and may not manifest symptoms of the disease until 3-6 months of age, when they develop:

  • Progressive macrocephaly,
  • Severe hypotonia,
  • Persistent head lag, and
  • Delayed milestones.

As the disease progresses, there is spasticity, joint stiffness, and contractures. Optic Atrophy and seizures subsequently develop.

Macrocephaly related causes:

  • Alexander syndrome,
  • Canavan disease,
  • Sotos syndrome,
  • Gangliosidosis,
  • Hydrocephalus,
  • Mucopolysaccharidosis,
  • Subdural effusion
  • Glutaric acidemia type 1

Other options:

  • Metachromatic leukodystrophy is caused by a deficiency of arylsulfatase A, results in the white matter storage of sulphated glycosphingolipids, which leads to demyelination and a neurodegenerative course.
  • Pompe disease, also referred to as GSD type II or acid maltase deficiency, is caused by a deficiency of acid α-1,4-glucosidase, an enzyme responsible for the degradation of glycogen in lysosomes. Affected infants present in the first days to weeks of life with:
    1. Hypotonia,
    2. Generalized muscle weakness with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with feeding difficulties,
    3. Macroglossia, and
    4. Hepatomegaly
  • Krabbe's disease, also called globoid cell leukodystrophy, is due to the deficiency of the enzymatic activity of galactocerebrosidase & is rapidly progressive, and patients present in early infancy with irritability, seizures, and hypertonia. As the disease progresses, optic atrophy and severe developmental delay become apparent; affected children exhibit opisthotonos and typically die before 3 years of age.

Causes of Microcephaly:

  • Neuronal migration disorders
  • Rett Syndrome
  • Seckel syndrome
  • Maternal TORCH Infections
  • Radiation exposure
  • Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Fetal hydantoin syndrome
  • Perinatal asphyxia
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Lysosomal storage disorders

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT associated with increase in the risk of seizures in future in a child with febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
After an initial febrile seizure, 3-12% children develop epilepsy by adolescence.

The risk of epilepsy is 1.5-2.4% for simple febrile seizures and increases in children with:

  • Pre-existing neurodevelopmental abnormality;
  • complex febrile seizure; and
  • family history of epilepsy.

Note: Diagnostic criteria for febrile seizures:

  • Age: 6 months - 5 years
  • Temperature: 38 degree Celsius(100.4 degree Fahrenheit) or higher
  • No Neurological abnormality
  • No post ictal neurological deficit

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl presented with early morning clumsiness and several episodes of breaking dishes and glasses at breakfast. She describes few uncontrollable brief jerks of her shoulders and arms and few episodes of blood in her mouth from biting her tongue. Her examination is normal, MRI brain normal, and an EEG, which showed a 4- to 6-Hz generelized polyspike-and-wave pattern. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (Janz syndrome) is the most common generalized epilepsy in young adults, with one or more of the following manifestations:

  • Myoclonic jerks in the morning, often causing the patient to drop things;
  • Generalized tonic-clonic or clonic-tonic- clonic seizures upon awakening; and
  • Juvenile absences.

EEG usually shows generalized 4-to 5-Hz polyspike-and-slow-wave discharges.

The genes involved are: GABRA 1, CLNC 2,Myoclonin 1

Treatment: Valproate

Other options:

  • Benign rolandic epilepsy Or benign childhood epilepsy with centrotemporal spikes (BECTS), typically starts during childhood (ages 3-10 years) and is outgrown by adolescence.
  • West syndrome starts between the ages of 2 and 12 months and consists of a triad of Infantile epileptic spasms that usually occur in clusters (particularly in drowsiness or upon awakening), Developmental regression, and typical EEG picture called hypsarrhythmia
  • Atypical absence seizures have associated myoclonic components and tone changes of the head (head drop) and body, usually last longer than typical absence seizures, and are also usually more difficult to treat. They are precipitated by drowsiness and are usually accompanied by 1-to 2-Hz spike-and-slow-wave discharges.

Extra edge: Diagnostic utility of electroencephalography in epilepsy

questions.text: Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy is a disease of:
questions.solution:
Dystrophinopathies are a group of disorders resulting from mutations in the dystrophin gene (located on short arm of X chromosome, Xp21). The dystrophin protein is responsible for stabilization of membrane. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is the most common dystrophinopathy with an incidence of 1 in 3500 live male births and present before 5 years of age. It is an X linked recessive disease. questions.text: An infant presents with hypotonia and hyporeflexia. During his intrauterine period there was polyhydramnios and decreased fetal movements. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Decreased fetal movements, polyhydramnios, hypotonia and hyporeflexia classically points to Spinal muscular atrophy diagnosis.

Other options:

  • Congenital myasthenia has nearly an onset at birth or in early infancy with symptoms that may include hypotonia, external ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, dysphagia, weak cry, facial weakness, easy muscle fatigue generally, and sometimes respiratory insufficiency or failure, precipitated by a minor respiratory infection. It is rarely seen before 12 mo.
  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome - Initial symptoms include numbness and paresthesia, followed by weakness that usually follows a nonspecific gastrointestinal or respiratory infection by approximately 10 days.
  • Muscular dystrophy - Infant boys with MD are rarely symptomatic at birth or in early infancy, although some are mildly hypotonic.

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought by parents with seizures and developmental delay. He has multiple hypopigmented macules over the back. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
More than 90% of Tuberous sclerosis patients show the typical hypomelanotic macules that have been linked to an ash leaf on the trunk and extremities, accompanied by seizures and developmental delays.

Other options:

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 presents with cafe-au-lait Macules, Axillary or inguinal freckling, neurofibromas.
  • Sturge Weber syndrome characterized by capillary malformation in the face (port-wine birthmark) and brain (leptomeninges), as well as glaucoma.
  • Linear Sebacous Nevus Syndrome is characterized by a large facial nevus, hemimegalencephaly, and systemic defects.

questions.text: A 4 years old girl presenting with severe mental retardation, recurrent seizures, ataxia and "puppet like gait" with a happy disposition prone to bouts of uncontrolled laughter is likely to have a defect in which chromosome
questions.solution:
Inheriting both chromosomes 15 from the father is functionally the same as deletion of the maternal 15q12 region and results in Angelman syndrome.

People with Angelman syndrome have severe intellectual disability with limited to no functional speech, Movement problems, seizures, behavioural issues and specific facial appearance.

questions.text: A 10 months child weighing 5 kg and with 65 cm length, presents with a cough and cold. He was observed to have a respiratory rate of 48 per minute with no retractions, cyanosis, grunting. There is no history of convulsion, which of the following statements is true according to IMNCI guidelines?
questions.solution:
According to the Integrated Management of Newborn and Childhood Illness (IMNCI) classification system, a child with a cough and cold but no signs of pneumonia is classified as "no pneumonia". This means that the child can be treated at home for their cough or cold without antibiotics

questions.text: A child of less than 1 year should use the following device for asthma treatment
questions.solution:
An infant should use MDI with spacer with mask for asthma.

Other options - It is very important to select an appropriate device by which the maintenance medication has to be administered.

Inhalation method should be chosen on individual basis but a rough guideline is as follows.

  • Children below 4 years of age: MDI with spacer with facemask can be used successfully.
  • For children above 4 years of age: MDI with spacer is preferred.
  • For children above 12 years of age: MDI may be used directly.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the office due to significant steatorrhea and failure to thrive. She has history of multiple respiratory tract infections. Auscultation reveals mild wheezing and diminished air entry in both lungs. Clubbing is visible on both hands. What is the most probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The above signs and symptoms points towards cystic fibrosis.

Key Aspects of CF:

  1. Genetics: CF is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, meaning both parents must carry a faulty CFTR gene for the child to be affected.
  2. Symptoms:
    • Persistent cough with thick mucus.
    • Recurrent pneumonias by Staphylococcus, Pseudomonas, Burkholderia
    • Frequent lung infections.
    • Difficulty breathing.
    • Poor growth and weight gain due to malabsorption.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Newborn screening.
    • Sweat chloride test (measures salt content in sweat).
    • Immunoreactive trypsinogen test
    • Nasal potential difference measurement
    • Genetic testing for CFTR mutations.
  4. Treatment:
    • Airway clearance techniques (chest physiotherapy, inhalers, mucolytics).
    • Medications (antibiotics, bronchodilators, CFTR modulators).
    • Enzyme supplements for digestion.
    • Lung transplant in severe cases.

CFTR modulator drugs are:

  • Ivacaftor
  • Lumacaftor
  • Elexacaftor
  • Tezacaftor

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-454, Page- 2668

questions.text: A 10 year old girl presented with fever, convulsions, neck rigidity. CSF findings are protein 150 mg, sugar 40 mg, chloride 2500 mg with lymphadenopathy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of tubercular meningitis is based on clinical features and investigations.

CSF typically shows raised pressure, up to 500 cells per mm3 with lymphocytic predominance, increased protein and low sugar (level about half the concomitant blood sugar level).

Other options -

  • Bacterial meningitis : CSF examination in bacterial meningitis reveals raised pressure, turbid fluid, markedly increased cell count (often in thousands per mm3) chiefly comprised of polymorphonuclear cells, increased protein and low sugar (less than 40% of the concomitant blood sugar).
  • Viral meningitis: CSF examination shows: normal pressure, slight raised cell count comprised of polymorphonuclear cells, slight increased protein and low sugar
  • Fungal meningitis: raised pressure, slight raised cell count comprised of polymorphonuclear cells, slight increased protein and normal sugar or may be decreased

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-643, Page- 3759

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency department with respiratory difficulty and noisy breathing. On examination, X-ray shows thumb sign. The diagnosis is -
questions.solution:
Acute Epiglottitis is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive and potentially fulminating course of high fever, sore throat, dyspnea, and rapidly progressing respiratory obstruction.

Classic radiographs of a child who has epiglottitis show the thumb sign.

Epiglottitis is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by the inflammation and swelling of the epiglottis, the flap of tissue at the base of the tongue that covers the trachea (windpipe) during swallowing to prevent food or liquid from entering the lungs. When the epiglottis becomes inflamed, it can rapidly swell, causing a blockage of the airway and leading to difficulty breathing. Epiglottitis is a medical emergency, especially in children.

Key Features of Epiglottitis:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Severe sore throat: Often disproportionate to clinical findings.
    • Difficulty swallowing (dysphagia): Pain when swallowing or inability to swallow.
    • Drooling: Due to difficulty swallowing.
    • Stridor: A high-pitched sound heard when breathing in, indicating airway obstruction.
    • Rapid onset of symptoms: Typically, within hours, and the condition worsens quickly.
    • Fever: Usually high, especially in bacterial cases.
    • Sitting in a "tripod" position: Leaning forward with the chin thrust out and mouth open to help breathe.
    • Cyanosis: Bluish tint to the lips or skin due to a lack of oxygen, indicating severe airway obstruction.
  2. Causes:
    • Bacterial infections: The most common cause is infection by the bacterium Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib). However, with the widespread use of the Hib vaccine, cases of epiglottitis have significantly decreased.
    • Other bacteria: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep), and Staphylococcus aureus (including MRSA) can also cause epiglottitis.
    • Viral infections, injuries, or thermal damage (e.g., from hot liquids) can occasionally cause epiglottitis, though less commonly.
  3. Diagnosis:
    • Clinical presentation: The symptoms, especially stridor and difficulty breathing, prompt suspicion of epiglottitis.
    • Laryngoscopy: Performed by a specialist, this visualizes the swollen, cherry-red epiglottis.
    • X-rays: In some cases, a lateral neck X-ray may show a characteristic "thumbprint" sign, indicating a swollen epiglottis.
    • Blood cultures or throat swabs: Can help identify the causative organism, especially if it's bacterial.
  4. Treatment:
    • Airway management: Since epiglottitis can lead to sudden airway obstruction, securing the airway is the priority. In severe cases, intubation or a tracheotomy (a surgical airway) may be necessary.
    • Antibiotics: If the cause is bacterial, broad-spectrum antibiotics (such as ceftriaxone or cefotaxime) are administered intravenously.
    • Corticosteroids: These may be given to reduce inflammation and swelling.
    • Hospitalization: Most patients with epiglottitis are treated in an intensive care unit (ICU) for close monitoring, particularly if airway intervention is needed.

Option A. Recurrent Respiratory Papillomatosis (RRP) is a rare medical condition caused by the growth of benign tumors (papillomas) in the respiratory tract, primarily in the larynx (voice box) but also potentially affecting other parts of the respiratory system such as the trachea, bronchi, and lungs. These growths are caused by infection with the human papillomavirus (HPV), particularly HPV types 6 and 11.

Key Features of RRP:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Hoarseness or changes in voice.
    • Chronic cough.
    • Difficulty breathing or stridor (a wheezing sound when breathing).
    • In severe cases, airway obstruction.
  2. Course of Disease:
    • The papillomas tend to recur after removal, which makes management difficult.
    • It can occur in both children (juvenile-onset RRP) and adults (adult-onset RRP).
  3. Transmission:
    • HPV transmission may occur during childbirth if a mother has genital warts (caused by HPV), leading to juvenile-onset RRP.
    • Adult-onset RRP is thought to be related to reactivation of a latent HPV infection.
  4. Treatment:
    • Surgical removal of the papillomas is the most common treatment, often using laser surgery or microdebriders. However, surgery may need to be repeated due to the recurrent nature of the disease.
    • Adjuvant therapies (such as antiviral medications or immunomodulatory agents like interferon) may be used in more severe cases.

Option B. Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is a common respiratory illness in children that causes inflammation and swelling in the larynx (voice box), trachea (windpipe), and bronchi (the airways leading to the lungs). Croup is typically caused by viral infections, particularly by the parainfluenza virus, but other viruses like respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), influenza, and adenovirus can also be responsible.

Key Features of Croup:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Barking cough: Often compared to the sound of a seal.
    • Stridor: A high-pitched, wheezing sound when the child inhales, particularly during periods of agitation or crying.
    • Hoarseness: Due to inflammation of the vocal cords.
    • Fever: Typically mild, but may accompany the illness.
    • Difficulty breathing: Severe cases can cause respiratory distress due to airway narrowing.
  2. Age Group:
    • Croup most commonly affects children aged 6 months to 3 years, although older children can occasionally develop the condition.
  3. Course of Illness:
    • Symptoms often begin with cold-like signs such as a runny nose and fever.
    • The barking cough and stridor tend to worsen at night.
    • Symptoms usually peak within 2-3 days and resolve within a week, but the severity can vary.

Treatment:

  • Mild cases: Can often be managed at home. Parents are advised to keep the child calm, as crying and agitation can worsen symptoms. Humidified air and cool-mist humidifiers are sometimes recommended, though evidence for their effectiveness is mixed.
  • Medications: Steroids (such as dexamethasone or prednisolone) may be given to reduce airway inflammation. In more severe cases, nebulized epinephrine can be administered to reduce airway swelling and ease breathing.
  • Hospitalization: May be required for severe cases where the child is having significant difficulty breathing, or if the stridor is present at rest.

Option D. Tonsillitis is an inflammation of the tonsils, the two oval-shaped tissues located at the back of the throat, which play a role in the immune system by helping to fight off infections. It is common in children but can also affect adults. Tonsillitis can be caused by viral or bacterial infections, with streptococcal bacteria (strep throat) being a notable bacterial cause.

Key Features of Tonsillitis:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Sore throat: The most common symptom, often severe.
    • Red, swollen tonsils: Sometimes with white patches or pus (in cases of bacterial tonsillitis).
    • Difficulty swallowing: Pain while eating or drinking.
    • Fever: Often present, especially in bacterial infections.
    • Swollen lymph nodes: Particularly in the neck.
    • Bad breath: Halitosis due to infection.
    • Headache, fatigue, and ear pain: Less common but possible.
    • In young children, irritability and refusal to eat may also be signs.
  2. Causes:
    • Viral infections: Most cases are caused by common cold viruses (such as adenovirus, rhinovirus, or Epstein-Barr virus).
    • Bacterial infections: Group A streptococcus (strep throat) is the most common bacterial cause.
  3. Types:
    • Acute tonsillitis: Short-term, often viral, with symptoms lasting about 7-10 days.
    • Chronic tonsillitis: Long-term, recurrent infections that persist over time.
    • Recurrent tonsillitis: Frequent episodes of acute tonsillitis over a short period.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • A physical exam typically shows red, swollen tonsils, and possibly white patches (exudate).
    • A rapid strep test or throat culture may be done to identify bacterial causes, such as streptococcus.
  5. Treatment:
    • Viral tonsillitis: Usually resolves on its own with supportive care, such as rest, hydration, and pain relievers (e.g., acetaminophen or ibuprofen).
    • Bacterial tonsillitis: Antibiotics, typically penicillin or amoxicillin, are prescribed for streptococcal infections. It's important to complete the entire course of antibiotics to prevent complications like rheumatic fever.
    • Home care: Gargling with salt water, throat lozenges, and staying hydrated can help ease discomfort.
  6. Tonsillectomy:
    • In cases of chronic or recurrent tonsillitis, a tonsillectomy (surgical removal of the tonsils) may be recommended. Tonsillectomy is also considered if tonsillitis leads to complications such as difficulty breathing or obstructive sleep apnea.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-433, Page- 2570

questions.text: All of the following are complications of sinusitis except:
questions.solution:
Glomerulonephritis may be a complication of Group A beta-haemolytic streptococcus tonsillitis.

Other options -

Because of the close proximity of the paranasal sinuses to the brain and eyes, serious orbital and/or intracranial complications can result from acute bacterial sinusitis and progress rapidly.

Intracranial complications can include epidural abscess, meningitis, cavernous sinus thrombosis, subdural empyema, and brain abscess. Other complications include osteomyelitis of the frontal bone (Pott puffy tumor) and mucoceles.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter- 429, Page- 2556

choices.text: Most common congenital anomaly of larynx
It needs no treatment in most of the cases

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about laryngomalacia, except -
questions.solution:
Laryngomalacia stridor worsens on exertion or crying and disappears on prone position.

Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor (a high-pitched, noisy breathing sound) in infants. It occurs when the tissues of the larynx (voice box), particularly the epiglottis and the surrounding structures, are softer than normal and collapse inward during inhalation, causing partial airway obstruction. This condition is typically benign and self-limiting, meaning most children outgrow it as the structures of the larynx strengthen with age.

Key Features of Laryngomalacia:

  1. Symptoms:
    • Stridor: A high-pitched, squeaky or fluttering noise during inspiration heard when the infant breathes in. It is often more noticeable when the baby is feeding, crying, excited, or lying on their back.
    • Noisy breathing: Especially noticeable during feeding or sleep.
    • Feeding difficulties: Some infants may have trouble coordinating breathing and feeding.
    • Reflux: Gastroesophageal reflux is common in infants with laryngomalacia and may exacerbate symptoms.
    • Poor weight gain: In severe cases, feeding difficulties can lead to inadequate weight gain or failure to thrive.
    • Cyanosis or apnea: In very rare, severe cases, the infant may develop bluish skin (due to lack of oxygen) or episodes where they stop breathing momentarily.
  2. Onset and Course:
    • Age of onset: Symptoms of laryngomalacia usually appear shortly after birth, often within the first few weeks of life.
    • Course: Symptoms tend to worsen between 4-8 months as the baby grows, but most infants outgrow the condition by 12-18 months as their laryngeal structures strengthen and firm up.
  3. Causes:
    • The exact cause is unclear, but it is believed to result from delayed maturation of the laryngeal cartilages.
    • Some cases may be associated with neuromuscular conditions, which can lead to poor coordination of the muscles that support the airway.
  4. Diagnosis:
    • Physical examination and medical history: The typical noise and timing of stridor often provide clues for the diagnosis.
    • Flexible laryngoscopy: A small flexible camera is inserted through the nose to visualize the larynx and confirm the diagnosis. This is the gold standard for diagnosing laryngomalacia.
    • Other tests: In more severe cases, a sleep study, swallowing study, or imaging may be performed to assess the airway and rule out other causes of airway obstruction.
  5. Treatment:
    • Mild cases: Most infants with laryngomalacia do not need treatment, as the condition is typically self-limiting. Supportive care, such as feeding in an upright position and monitoring symptoms, is usually sufficient.
    • Reflux management: Gastroesophageal reflux is common in infants with laryngomalacia, and treatment with acid-reducing medications (e.g., proton pump inhibitors or H2 blockers) may be helpful.
    • Severe cases: In rare instances where the condition leads to significant breathing difficulties, failure to thrive, or frequent choking, surgery may be necessary.
    • Supraglottoplasty: This is a surgical procedure that trims the excess tissue causing airway obstruction. It is usually very effective in improving breathing and reducing symptoms.
  6. Prognosis:
    • Most infants with laryngomalacia improve as they grow older, with symptoms resolving by 12-18 months of age.

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics, 22nd edition, Chapter-434, Page-2573
